questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Yes -
By moving much of Azure's software-defined networking stack off the CPUs and into FPGA-based SmartNICs, compute cycles are reclaimed by end user applications, putting less load on the VM, decreasing jitter and inconsistency in latency.

Box 2: Yes -

Box 3: No -
Accelerated Networking (AN) is generally available (GA) and widely available for Windows and the latest distributions of Linux
Reference:
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/maximize-your-vm-s-performance-with-accelerated-networking-now-generally-available-for-both-windows-and-linux/

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

HOTSPOT -
You have an SAP environment that contains the following components:
✑ Enhancement Package 6 for SAP ERP Central Component 6.0 (SAP ECC 6.0)
✑ Servers that run SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 (SLES 12)
✑ Databases on IBM DB2 10.5
✑ SAP Solution Manager 7.1
You plan to migrate the SAP environment to Azure.
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content:
Agreed.
To get full solman support, version 7.2 is currently required for both on-premise and virtual environment. Version 7.1 has been already out of mainstream maintenance.
So, answer is No.

discussion.content: After six years, mainstream maintenance for SAP Solution Manager 7.1 has ended on December 31, 2017. Customers still using the 7.1 release have transitioned to customer-specific maintenance automatically .I think Ans is - No
Yes,Yes,No
Yes, Yes, No

SAP ECC 6.0 and higher is supported on Azure and Solution Manager above 7.0. 

YES YES NO
YES, YES and NO

I have a doubt about SM 7.1 support in Azure. Reading note 1928533 the OS is supported, the DB2 version is supported, ABAP stack is supported (7.02), the kernel is supported (7.21) but the support for Java AS start from 7.1 while SM 7.1 is Dual Stack with Java 7.02 Components. In case of Dual Stack Split (the Java components will be clearly not supported). I don't find any specific and clear info about this case. 
Right Answers: Yes?, Yes, No.
Yes, Yes, No

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Yes -

Box 2: No -
Upgrade to ECC 7.01 or later.

Box 3: No -
With Microsoft Azure, you can migrate your existing SAP application running on IBM Db2 for Linux, UNIX, and Windows (LUW) to Azure virtual machines. With
SAP on IBM Db2 for LUW, administrators and developers can still use the same development and administration tools, which are available on-premises.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-factory/connector-sap-table https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/dbms_guide_ibm

Box 1: Software Update Manager (SUM) Database Migration option (DMO) with System Update
The SAP ERP system is 6.06.
Box 2: Software Update Manager (SUM) Database Migration option (DMO) without System Update
The portal is SAP NetWeaver 7.3.
SAP ERP portal migrate azure Software update manager database
Reference:
https://blogs.sap.com/2017/10/05/your-sap-on-azure-part-2-dmo-with-system-move/

discussion.content: DMO with MOVE for ECC and Heterogeneous copy for portal..DMO is not for JAVA systems

comments.content: DMO is only for ABAP based system
Portal and ECC targeting systems are HANA. DMO valid for both migration

discussion.content: For portal it should heterogeneous copy. DMO is not supported for portal

for ECC: SUM&DMO with System MOVE. ( SUM&DMO manages the software upgrade and migration to HANA, and the "System Move" option takes care of the move to Cloud)
for Portal: Heterogeneous copy.

comments.content: HANA will be use (no need of Oracle anymore) => 1. SUM+DMO+System update

discussion.content:
Oracle is not Supported on SLES => Heterogeneous system copy
For Portal => SUM+DMO+System update.

Answer is correct. 
NetWeaver version is supported. 
ERP version needs upgrade. Also there is a move from AnyDB to SAP HANA

Ans-
1) SUM+DMO+System update.
2) Heterogeneous system copy. HANA 1.0 is supported with NW 7.3 along with SLES 12, RHEL 7 and WIN server 2016/2019.

Right Answers should be:
Heth System Copy for Portal. (DMO is only for ABAP System)
SUM with DMO with System Move for ERP 6.0 EHP6 (Upgrade + Migration to Az in one step)

comments.content: NW 7.3 is supported on HANA 1.0 (from PAM)

discussion.content: Important observation is for ERP 6.06 i.e it is EHP6 and product supported on SAP HANA is EHP7 and above.So the first option is SUM,DMO and system update and second option is Heterogeneous copy.

comments.content: correct, NW 7.3 portal need to be 7.4 or above
NetWeaver 7.00 and above is supported on Azure.

discussion.content: As it's move to azure , it will be DMO with system Move for both

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have an on-premises SAP environment that runs on SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES) servers and Oracle. The version of the SAP ERP system is 6.06 and the version of the portal is SAP NetWeaver 7.3.
You need to recommend a migration strategy to migrate the SAP ERP system and the portal to Azure. The solution must be hosted on SAP HANA.
What should you recommend? To answer, drag the appropriate tools to the correct components. Each tool may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
NZDM is not possible for :
● SUM with Database Migration Option (DMO)
● SUM with S/4HANA Conversion, if DMO is contained
For availability and scenarios, check SAP Note 1678565 - Prerequisites, Terms and Conditions for nZDM/SUM. I feel that SUM with DMO is correct option

Why not B?
B. Use Near-Zero Downtime (NZDT) to migrate to SAP HANA and Azure during the same maintenance window.

comments.content: Because it is a service and not yet available for migration to cloud.

discussion.content: correct

questions.answer_description:
The SAP Database Migration Option (DMO) with System Move option of SUM, used as part of the migration allows customer the options to perform the migration in a single step, from source system on-premises, or to the target system residing in Microsoft Azure, minimizing overall downtime.
Reference:
https://blogs.sap.com/2017/10/05/your-sap-on-azure-part-2-dmo-with-system-move/

choices.B: Use Near-Zero Downtime (NZDT) to migrate to SAP HANA and Azure during the same maintenance window.
choices.A: Migrate SAP ECC to SAP Business Suite in HANA, and then migrate SAP to Azure.
choices.C: Use the Database Migration Option (DMO) to migrate to SAP HANA and Azure during the same maintenance window.
choices.D: Migrate SAP to Azure, and then migrate SAP ECC to SAP Business Suite on HANA.

questions.question_text:
You are evaluating which migration method Litware can implement based on the current environment and the business goals.
Which migration method will cause the least amount of downtime?

comments.content:
This is a tricky question, but I prefer YES, NO, YES.
If you answer YES, NO, NO. I cannot say you are wrong, because that is the case.
And you even should say that we cannot guarantee the file that you deleted today for example. Isn't it? because the file may be created today!

discussion.content:
The YES, NO, NO is for the case in which the file was created after the retention policy was activated, and depending when the file was created & subsequently deleted relative to the backup schedule, the ability to recover the file is not guaranteed - @Ksseba gave a good example of that.
But if the file existed before the policy was activated, the answer is YES, NO, YES - as either based on monthly of early backups, we should be able to recover some instance of that file ( but by no means, the latest copy of the file before deletion).
YES, NO, NO

It depends on when the deleted file was created. In case the file was created last year between two monthly backups and deleted before the next monthly backup, one won't be able to recover it. Answer is YES NO NO
YES NO YES

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You are evaluating the proposed backup policy.
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Yes -
Scenario: Technical requirements: Ensure that an application server can be restored from a backup created during the last five days within 15 minutes.
Instant Restore has 'The instance recovery snapshot(s) for 5 Day(s)'.

Box 2: No -
Scenario: Ensure that all the production application servers can restore daily backups from the last 21 days.
The Retention of daily backup point is set to for 14 days only.

Box 3: Yes -
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/backup/backup-instant-restore-capability
